dek: How 390 high school dress codes are still sexualizing their students in 2019.
author: Amber Thomas
assistance: with data collection assistance from Kait Thomas and Anna Houston
preamble: If you aren't currently in high school, it's probably been a while since you've read a student handbook. Over the past few months, my colleagues and I have pored over 481 of them from schools across the US. We focused specifically on the dress code section — a set of policies hotly debated for being racist, sexist, and promoting sexualization. This is a story about exploring that last claim and what we found along the way.
introQuestion: In early 2017, writer Dana Schwartz posed a question to the Twitter-verse: "Ladies, when was the first time you were made to feel embarrassed and sexualized for what you wore?"

introMemory.value: I thought of my earliest memories of this type of behavior — the times when I wasn‚Äôt aiming to be ‚Äúsexy‚Äù, but was perceived that way anyway. I remembered the girls stopped outside of our middle school dance because their shoulders and underarms were bare. Being handed a detention slip because a small sliver of my torso was exposed. Like Dana, each of my earliest memories of feeling sexualized came from the adults that were trying to enforce my school‚Äôs dress code.
I like to imagine that this wasn‚Äôt done maliciously. I mean, it‚Äôs not like my school‚Äôs policy literally said anything like this:

convo1ReceivedText: Ladies, your bodies are too sexy and need to be covered up. üôà

introMessage.value: But that doesn‚Äôt mean that I hadn‚Äôt still received that message. Like so much else in life, words can often hold hidden meanings or insinuations.

When dealing with only the written word, humans and computers are both pretty terrible at separating out the text from their underlying meanings. It‚Äôs why many online users have started using the ‚Äú/s‚Äù notation to indicate that their words should be taken sarcastically, not literally.

All of this makes analyzing dress codes a challenge. Following the lead of researchers studying dress codes in California and Washington DC, we collected data from hundreds of high schools to learn more about what they prohibit and why these policies exist. Interpreting the hidden messages the policies send, however, is trickier. We‚Äôll rely on research and reports to help add some context around why some people say these policies sexualize students.

bodyIntro.value: Although the name may imply that dress codes are merely involved with regulating the clothes that students may wear, we found that 77% of schools‚Äô policies specifically prohibited certain body parts from being visible. Those phrases often looked something like this:

bodyExample: [Students may not wear] clothing that bares or exposes traditionally private parts of the body including, but not limited to, the stomach, buttocks, back and breasts.

body-examples.text: [Students may not wear] clothing that bares or exposes traditionally private parts of the body including, but not limited to, the stomach, buttocks, back and breasts.
Shirts must cover the midriff and must cover the chest area (cleavage must be covered).

bodyPostExample.value: Policies like these have recently come under scrutiny. According to opponents, at best, by prohibiting certain body parts from being visible, students receive the message that those body parts are bad, should be hidden, or are of importance to others. At worst, some say that dress codes go so far as to turn whole people into a collection of inappropriate body parts to cover.
According to our analysis, these are the body parts that schools think are most in need of covering.

bodyPostMultiple: You may have begun to notice some trends amongst the dress code policies. These may become clearer if we aggregate the data from all 481 schools in our dataset.

bodyPreExplore.value: I won‚Äôt lie, I was expecting something like genitals to be number one here, but only 6 schools (1%) explicitly ban them. Midriffs, on the other hand — the front part of your body between your chest and your waist — is the most banned body part by a long shot. Which raises the question: why?

The stomach and belly button are not inherently sexual body parts. Though, in Western culture, the midriff, and navel in particular, has a long history of being seen as taboo or indecent. Specifically, the female midriff. Women couldn‚Äôt show their belly buttons on television until the 1970‚Äôs or the streets of New York City until 1985. Arguments go on about whether baring the female midriff is fashionable, erotic, or attractive to those looking at her, but always seem to focus on the people that are observing someone else‚Äôs midriff, rather than the person baring their own.

Of course, midriffs aren‚Äôt the only body part more commonly policed in women than in men. It happens often enough that author Sady Doyle posited ‚Äú[e]very woman has a moment when she realizes her body is public property‚Äù. We see this in social media, politics, sports, and even the Super Bowl Halftime Show. And of course, we see it in high school dress codes.
Below, explore the body parts banned in each dress code.

bodyGridNote: Note: A few states are missing from this analysis because they did not have any schools listed in the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) database that met our criteria. All school size and locale data came from NCES.

bodyOutro.value: This practice of commenting on someone else‚Äôs body and imposing sexuality upon them (whether they intended to be ‚Äúsexy‚Äù or not) falls squarely into the American Psychological Association‚Äôs (APA) definition of sexualization. Compounding the issue, some argue, is that by telling and showing students that these body parts are important to others, we are reinforcing the idea that those parts should be important to them too. And when things are important to us, we tend to be highly aware of them. Unfortunately, studies have shown that when people are consciously thinking about their appearance, they perform worse on various cognitive tasks like math tests and are more likely to experience eating disorders, low self-esteem, and depression.

clothesIntro.value: Beyond hiding specific body parts, dress code policies typically list a number of items that students are not allowed to wear to school. The average school‚Äôs dress code prohibits around 32 things (the maximum was at 97). Here are some snippets of what these policies may look like:

clothes-examples.text: Shorts and skirt length must be as long, or longer than, the longest fingertip. Shorts and skirts that pass this test may still be deemed inappropriate.
Low-cut tops, spaghetti straps, halter tops, backless tops, tube tops, A-shirts (muscle shirts), clothing that allows for bare midriffs, low necklines, and/or short shorts are not allowed.

clothesMid.value: Many school‚Äôs policies range from prohibiting bare feet or hats to spiked jewelry or promotions of alcohol. Let‚Äôs focus specifically on clothing items that are worn on your body.  This includes any form of shirt, pants, shorts, skirts, dresses, and undergarments.

Although many of these rules are technically written to apply to all students evenly, in practice, quite a few of them affect some students more than others. For instance, although male students are also not allowed to wear halter tops, that fashion item is typically made for and marketed to girls.
Let‚Äôs see which of the banned clothing items are specifically marketed to girls, boys, or students of any gender.

clothesSteps.text: Here we‚Äôve arranged all of the clothing items based on how frequently they are banned.
You‚Äôll find short shorts and skirts at the highest end alongside visible underwear.
On the opposite end, you‚Äôll find items banned in fewer schools like spandex clothing, gym shorts, and the absence of underwear.

You may have noticed that almost all of these items are likely prohibited because they reveal or accentuate parts of the body. In fact, there are only 4 (pajamas, loose clothing, very long shirts, and cutoff pants) that seem to be banned for some other reason.

Of the remaining 37 items, 59% are marketed to girls, 35% to any gender, and only 6% are marketed to boys. Once again, we see that the bodies and clothes that girls wear are more highly regulated than other students.

clothesGraphTitle: Percentage of High Schools Which Prohibit Clothing Items
clothingNotesText: Note: * the definition of ‚Äúshort‚Äù varies from school to school. The most common lengths for shorts, skirts, and dresses were ‚Äúto the students fingertips‚Äù (53%), ‚Äúlonger than mid-thigh‚Äù (36%), and ‚Äúlonger than the knee‚Äù (11%). Another 33% didn‚Äôt specify a length, just prohibited ‚Äúshort‚Äù items of clothing. ‚ÄúShort‚Äù shirts refers typically to shirts that can‚Äôt be tucked in or touch the top of the pants.

clothesOutro.value: Some people posit that girl‚Äôs clothes are more regulated because boys have fewer clothing options. Afterall, their shirts, pants, and shorts are all largely the same style.

Girls clothing, on the other hand, has a wider variety of style options, a much smaller proportion of which are allowed in many of the schools we surveyed. In a study of clothes available for girls (sizes 8-14) in online stores, 41% of girls clothing in ‚Äútween‚Äù stores like Abercrombie Kids, were considered sexualized. That is, they exposed or accentuated the ‚Äúsexualized‚Äù parts of the body (e.g., midriffs, cleavage, etc.). These clothes probably wouldn‚Äôt meet the requirements of most dress codes we analyzed, meaning that ‚Äúacceptable‚Äù girls clothing choices are severely limited compared to what is available to purchase.

While I haven‚Äôt found a similar study on clothes sized for high school students, I can‚Äôt imagine that clothes for older teens are less sexualized than clothes for their middle-school peers. If you‚Äôre looking for personal anecdotes of frustrated teens and parents who can‚Äôt find clothes to satisfy the dress code requirements, you don‚Äôt have to look far. One mother even snarkily invited the school‚Äôs principal to take her daughter shopping since she had had no luck in finding shorts that were fingertip length, within budget, and remotely stylish.

wordsTitle: The Words We Tell Our Students

wordsIntro.value: Even after dress codes ban body parts and clothes that expose the body, making it clear that some parts of you should be hidden, the words we use further reinforce this idea. Most dress codes begin with a few sentences informing the reader what a dress code is for and why it exists.  Some others give a brief explanation as to why a particular item has been prohibited. Here are a few examples:

word-examples.text: Bizarre, immodest or revealing clothing demeans the value of the wearer and disrupts the educational atmosphere. It will not be permitted.
The purpose of the Dress Code is to encourage students to focus on the learning process without the distractions of unsuitable dress and grooming.

Students are encouraged to ask themselves the following questions when choosing what to wear to school:
Does my outfit promote modesty and respectability?
Does my choice of clothing make those around me uncomfortable?
Does my clothing expose too much?
The district‚Äôs dress code is established to teach grooming and hygiene, prevent disruption, and minimize safety hazards.

wordsMid.value: Our words matter. Whether intentionally or not, some of these dress codes are literally telling students that their bodies and modes of dress are distractions or linked to their value or self worth. And as we‚Äôve already seen, it is largely the female students that are receiving these messages.
We manually extracted the most common words used to offer any rationale for the dress code policies. Explore some examples of the most common words and phrases below.

wordsPostExplore.value: Policies using phrases like ‚Äúdistract‚Äù or ‚Äúdisrupt‚Äù are in the vast majority, representing 76% of the schools in our dataset. The phrasing has not gone unnoticed by students. Back in 2014, students began using the hashtag #IAmNotADistraction in retaliation of policies just like these. Afterall, when girls are reprimanded for being ‚Äúdistracting‚Äù they are likely not distracting themselves. The typical argument falls that they are distracting their male classmates and, disturbingly, sometimes adult men.

Some suggest that creating dress codes like the ones we‚Äôve seen sends a complex message to all students. Specifically, it relays to girls that they are responsible for the way that others see them (and continuing that line of logic, what others do to them) and it relays to boys that they are not in control of their own actions and that they can pass judgement on others based on their appearance. If these are the lessons that students are learning, it‚Äôs not a far leap to understand why victims of sexual assault are often asked ‚Äúwhat were you wearing?‚Äù when they were assaulted, as if their clothing choices excuse the violence they endured.

Beyond the deeper messages, enforcing and even following a dress code can be difficult because the words used in dress codes are often incredibly vague. What one administrator may deem ‚Äúappropriate‚Äù would be cause for violation through the eyes of another. When it comes to the actual enforcement of these rules, 50% of schools specifically state that the final determination in whether or not a student is breaking the dress code will be a subjective one. Those clauses often look like this:

subj-examples.text: Any clothing or personal item that, in the judgment of the administration, interferes with or disrupts the educational process will not be allowed.
Decency, as interpreted by the administration and staff, is to be maintained at all time.

wordsOutro.value: Bringing subjectivity into this makes something tricky even more complicated because it brings along bias. Reports indicate that students that are ‚Äúcurvy‚Äù or ‚Äúbusty‚Äù are reprimanded more than their less-curvy classmates. Similarly, girls of color, whom are stereotypically perceived as ‚Äúhypersexualized‚Äù, ‚Äúprovocative‚Äù, and ‚Äúnot ladylike‚Äù are disproportionately targeted. They are found in violation of their school‚Äôs dress codes more often than their white classmates, even when both were breaking the rules.

The racial bias intertwined with these phrases doesn‚Äôt stop with the sexualization of students, either. Vague words like ‚Äúclean‚Äù and ‚Äúneat‚Äù may appear to exist in a student handbook to ensure that students are showering, but the phrases have also been used to penalize Black girls for wearing their hair naturally. The same goes for words like ‚Äúsafe‚Äù which seem like they would prevent students from wearing those dangerous wheelie-sneakers from the early 2000‚Äôs. While they may be used for that purpose, they are also used to regulate clothes that reinforce ‚Äú[ideas of] criminality‚Äù like the hoodies and sagging pants worn primarily by boys of color. Honestly, there‚Äôs enough racial bias in dress codes that the topic deserves its own article.

whatToDo.value: If you have never had to fight against these policies, the pushback may seem petty. But keep in mind, breaking dress code policies often leads to missed class time while students change, wait for their parents to bring a change of clothes, or have to travel home to get a replacement. The stakes may seem low but students‚Äô education is at stake.

Even so, some supporters are wondering where this fight ends. Author, Melissa Schorr asks: ‚Äú[I]s the end game to achieve equality by wearing the skimpiest clothes? Reflexively fighting against all dress code violations brushes aside the reality that there is a time and place for appropriate clothing.‚Äù

Others still wonder why opponents are fighting policies, when research has shown that people do make assumptions about others based on their appearance. When women wear clothes that are ‚Äúrevealing‚Äù, leave a few buttons undone on her blouse, or don‚Äôt dress according to accepted societal ‚Äúdress codes‚Äù, they are viewed as less competent, intelligent, and powerful than other women. Another study found that ‚Äúrevealing‚Äù clothes led viewers to assign less agency to the wearer. These findings don‚Äôt stop with adults — 5th grade girls wearing sexualized clothing were also seen as ‚Äúless than‚Äù.

Regan A. R. Gurung, author of 2 of the above studies, suggests that the issue is less with what people wear, and more with the mental link the observer makes between someone‚Äôs attire and their intelligence or competence. Basically, dress codes are a symptom of a larger societal issue: sexism. And students seem to get that. In an interview, Maggie Sunseri, creator of the documentary Shame: A Documentary on School Dress Code said "It's about the message behind the dress codes. It's not about just superficially what we're wearing, it's about what people are telling us that means about ourselves."

While taking on ages of systemic sexism may seem like a daunting task, working with your local schools to ameliorate the messages in their dress code policies is a lot more manageable and is one way to chip away at the bigger problem. The National Women‚Äôs Law Center has some suggestions for doing just that. Among them: include policies that maintain gender neutrality, don‚Äôt remove students from the classroom for dress code violations, and survey the students about how the dress code policies affect them. The Oregon chapter of the National Organization for Women (Oregon NOW) has also created a model dress code policy that they say does not ‚Äúreinforce or increase marginalization or oppression of any group based on race, gender, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, household income, gender identity or cultural observance‚Äù.

methodsTitle: Methods • Download the Data Here

methods.value: All school handbooks were chosen for analysis opportunistically as follows:

Using the National Center for Education Statistic‚Äôs (NCES) search function for public schools, I collected a list of over 8,000 public high schools in the US. I limited the resulting schools to just those that had a web address listed in NCES. Accessing the homepage web content from each site, I searched for words like ‚Äúhandbook‚Äù, ‚Äúdress code‚Äù, and ‚Äúcode of conduct‚Äù, filtering my list of schools to just those that contain one of the above phrases. Then, I manually visited the resulting (2,000+) websites in an attempt to find the dress code. Dress codes were disqualified from analysis if they: had a uniform policy, were not from the 2018-2019 school year, or represented magnet or boarding schools (according to the NCES).

Once the list of dress codes was compiled, I and two data assistants (Kait Thomas and Anna Houston) manually recorded every rule listed in each dress code, the words used in the dress code‚Äôs rationale, as well as any listed sanctions for breaking the dress code. Only items and body parts that were explicitly listed were included in this analysis. Some minor subjectivity came into play when combining similar phrases from different handbooks (ex. ‚Äúmidriff shirt‚Äù = ‚Äúcrop top‚Äù, ‚Äúshirt with open sides‚Äù = ‚Äúmuscle shirt‚Äù etc.).

Some data collected (e.g., sanctions for breaking the dress code, prohibited items not worn on the body — footwear, headwear, grooming, promotions of specific things, etc. — specific strap widths, specific length restrictions etc.) were not presented in this article. Those data are still available for public download and use here.

more.value: In the larger conversation around school dress codes, the sexualization of students is simply one part. Luckily, some amazing work has been done focusing on this and other areas as well:

The authors of this report also discuss the impact of uniform policies on families and suggestions for how educators and policymakers can improve dress codes.
